quest_name: Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a

history.location_text:
Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a jump... higher! Even higher! One step forward. Squat down, stand up straight. One jump forward, one jump back - don't turn! Stand up, stop wincing and nursing your tail base... Not bad at all.

I think you are the one we need, Ranger. Our scholars invented a unique device, which was sent to the Institute of Inventions and Innovations on planet Bonnasis for patenting. Unfortunately, we didn't have time to test it thoroughly so now we can't complete the application for the patent. There is only one test remaining - field-testing - but it is the most important one. We have already rented a test lab in the Institute and invited stuntmen but they failed to complete the testing.

As a ranger, you must be perfectly trained. We will even pay you twice as much as a stuntman gets - it makes 65535 cr, if you go to planet Bonnasis (system Procyon) and manage to test the device. But keep in mind that the patent submission is due to expire, so you must do all the testing by 6 February 3000.
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
You took an aerocab that brought you to the Inventions and Innovations. It was near the Academy of Anthropological and Amorphous Anomalies. You entered and asked which way you should go.

A gloomy assistant accompanied you along the tortuous corridors. You met a Maloq with a stunt man's badge hopping with his crutches, then they carried by a litter with an unconscious man - your colleague. A gaal in a wheelchair saw where you were going. Then he approached you, gave you a sympathising look, and mentioned quietly: "Heh, he's so young", - after that he wheeled away.

The assistant brought you to the "Test laboratory No 13" and kindly opened the door.
- Ranger? - a fae stood up to meet you. - Nice to meet you, I'm professor Hab, I manage the testing of the device and collect all the information necessary for the patent application preparation. Have a sit.
You sat obediently on the offered chair.
- Stand up, now sit down again. Bounce on your toes. Higher. Still higher! Now hold your breath. Hold your left ear with your right hand and the right ear with your left hand... Not mine!!!
He measured your pulse and nodded with satisfaction.
- Excellent. Pulse, co-ordination, reflexes  - you are in perfect shape and this is very important for the "Jumper"'s testing. By the way, you may breathe.

You exhaled with relief:
choices: What exactly am I supposed to do?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- You must test the jumping backpack - "Jumper". We rented a pavilion for the testing and tossed a facility. Your task is to go through the labyrinth made of hanging platforms jumping from one platform to another using the "Jumper". The labyrinth consists of the starting and finishing points and five rows of platforms between them.  Your task is to make a number of jumps to get from the starting point through the labyrinth to the finishing point . And you can jump only within the row you are at or onto the platforms of the next row.

Jumps require power consumption, which is measured in ergo and depends on the length of the jump. You will have two batteries  20 ergo each. One battery is active, and the other is spare. Our technicians promise that would be enough.

There are additional devices somewhere on the platforms, which allow you to replace the active battery, top it up or even get back to the starting point where you can charge the both batteries and start the testing from the very beginning. If you want to cancel the testing and, accordingly, abandon your fee, you can use the emergency return button.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re at the very start of the “Jumper” test and we don’t yet have the crucial information needed to plan a safe, battery-efficient route: the actual layout of the platforms across the five rows (how many platforms per row, their positions, any gaps or “dead ends”), and the rules details about allowed moves. Since our goal is to reach the finish without wasting energy or being forced into an emergency reset, the first strategic step is to request the labyrinth’s configuration so we can map possible paths and anticipate where we might need to conserve or where a longer jump is unavoidable. Power consumption and special devices matter too, but without the layout, we can’t evaluate jump costs intelligently. So the best move now is to get the full configuration explanation.

ACTION: 2

Power consumption and special devices matter too, but without the layout, we can’t evaluate jump costs intelligently. So the best move now is to get the full configuration explanation.

history.location_text:
Instead of answering Hab pointed to the window opening to the testing pavilion. There were half a dozen of platforms about two meters in diameter each hanging behind the window at a height of almost 20 meters. The distance between them was from 2 to 10 meters. The platforms were white with one coloured stripe along the edge.

- There are five rows of platforms here, each row is marked with a certain colour. The technicians changed the configuration many times already making the facility easier and safer, so I have only general information about its structure: 
- Starting point
- Yellow row - 4 platforms
- Red row - 4 platforms
- Violet row - 5 platforms, plus one battery charger
- Blue row - 4 platforms, the teleport can be used here
- Green row - 3 platforms, the teleport is active here too
- Final point - the testing is over here.

I would advise you to drag your heels here and study the facility's structure first. When you reach the Green or Blue row, you will be able to return to the starting point, charge your batteries and do the testing from the beginning. But note - you can do it just once.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We now know the row counts and that Violet has a charger, and Blue/Green have a one-time return-to-start teleport. However, we still lack the most important planning variable: how many ergo each jump costs as a function of distance (and whether there are any fixed overheads). With two 20-ergo batteries, efficient routing and knowing when to swap/charge are entirely dependent on the consumption curve. Before stepping onto the platforms, we should obtain the exact power consumption rules so we can budget energy, decide whether aiming for the Violet charger is mandatory, and understand how risky longer 8–10m jumps are. Once we know costs, we can then ask about the “additional devices” specifics if needed, and only then begin.

history.location_text:
Depending on the length of the jump, the power consumption will be the following:

2 meters - 4 ergo 
3-4 meters - 5 ergo
5 meters - 7 ergo
6-7 meters - 8 ergo
8 meters - 10 ergo
9-12 meters - 15 ergo

Our technicians promise that 40 ergo will be enough to go through the labyrinth. You are given two batteries  20 ergo each. Only one battery can be active - its power is used for the jump. But you can replace the battery with the help of the special device - there are such samples in the test labyrinth.

REASONING: We now have the critical jump cost table and know we have 40 ergo total across two 20-ergo batteries, but there’s a key constraint: only one battery can be active, and swapping requires a “special device” located somewhere in the labyrinth. Also, we know there’s a charger on Violet and a one-time return-to-start teleport on Blue/Green. Before we enter, we must understand exactly what these additional devices do and how they work: where/when we can swap the active battery, whether the Violet charger tops up the active battery only or both, whether it requires being on a specific platform, and any limitations/risks. Without these operational details, we could easily get stuck with an empty active battery while still holding a full spare we can’t access, or waste the one-time teleport/reset at the wrong time. Therefore, the best next step is to ask for details on additional devices.

history.location_text:
- In the first place, you can replace the active battery with the spare one  on every platform with an even number  and use it for jumping.
Secondly, there is a charger installed on the central platform of the Violet row  - it adds 12 ergo to the active battery automatically.
Thirdly, there is an accelerator on the first platform  of some row, I can't remember now which one. It will transfer you onto the first platform of the next sector just for 1 ergo. 
And of course, we will provide you with a portable teleport, which will help you to return to the starting point where you will be able to charge the both batteries and start from the beginning. But it's disposable and can be used only on the platforms of the Blue and Green rows!

What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We now understand the mechanics that will make or break the run: battery swapping only on even-numbered platforms, Violet’s central platform auto-charger (+12 ergo to the active battery), a mystery-row accelerator on the first platform of some row (1 ergo to jump to next sector’s first platform), and a one-time teleport back to start usable only on Blue/Green.

What we still don’t have is the concrete labyrinth configuration needed to plan a safe, energy-feasible route under these constraints: exact platform numbering per row, which platforms are “even”, distances between specific platforms (2–12m determines ergo cost), which platform is the “central” Violet platform, and where that accelerator might be relative to our likely path. Without that, stepping in now is gambling; we could get stuck on odd platforms unable to swap batteries, or miss the Violet charger, or be forced into 9–12m jumps (15 ergo) that blow the budget.

So the optimal next move is to demand more detailed configuration/how to go through it (ideally a layout/pathing explanation). Then we enter only once we can plan battery swaps and target the charger/teleport wisely.

history.location_text:
The professor wished you good luck and blessed you. Then he took you to the test pavilion.
- Note that the battery replacement devices are installed on the even platforms of each sector. Here is a portable teleport adjusted to return back here. You can use it only once - while passing the labyrinth' last two rows. The emergency return button means that you cancel the testing of just can't complete it. And in case of any accidents - well, you understand what I mean, mind your language and don't dirty the floor - our young ladies assisting in the lab have such a weak stomach.

You went up the stairs to the starting point. Meanwhile the professor and a dozen of his associates were making bets what platform you will fall from. 
"Snooks, lab rats", - you got furious and came to the edge. It is high! Round 20 meters, so the fall will be short but very painful. Well, you must jump. Which sector will you choose?
params: You are at the starting point
history.llm_response:
REASONING: First jump sets our energy economy and our flexibility with batteries. An 8-meter jump costs 10 ergo, which is a huge chunk of the active battery right away and risks forcing us into an early swap strategy. The 5–6 meter options are noticeably cheaper (7–8 ergo).  

We also must remember a critical constraint: we can only replace the active battery on **even-numbered platforms**. Starting on an even platform immediately preserves tactical flexibility—if the next moves force an awkward long jump or we burn down the active battery faster than expected, we’ll have the option to swap without needing to “hunt” for an even platform first.  

So I’ll avoid the 8-meter options and take the cheapest even landing: **Yellow-4 (6 meters = 8 ergo)**.

ACTION: 4
history.reasoning:
First jump sets our energy economy and our flexibility with batteries. An 8-meter jump costs 10 ergo, which is a huge chunk of the active battery right away and risks forcing us into an early swap strategy. The 5–6 meter options are noticeably cheaper (7–8 ergo).

So I’ll avoid the 8-meter options and take the cheapest even landing: **Yellow-4 (6 meters = 8 ergo)**.

history.location_text:
You hit your heels on the platform nastily and groaned with pain. There was an inscription along the very edge of the platform scratched with some sharp thing:
"Ranger Bob was here. 1 January 3000"

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Yellow-4 (even), so we *can* swap batteries here—but it’s not necessary yet. Battery №1 still has 12 ergo, enough for at least one solid jump, and keeping №2 (20 ergo) untouched as a reserve is valuable.

Also, since the Violet-row charger adds +12 to the **active** battery, we’ll eventually want the active battery to be relatively low when we reach that charger so we don’t waste potential charge (if there’s any cap). So spending down battery №1 first is sensible.

Best move now is progress into the next row while preserving flexibility. Jumping to Red-4 is 5 meters (7 ergo), leaving battery №1 at 5 ergo. Red-4 is also an even platform, so we should still have the option to swap there if needed.

ACTION: 3
history.reasoning:
We’re on Yellow-4 (even), so we *can* swap batteries here—but it’s not necessary yet. Battery №1 still has 12 ergo, enough for at least one solid jump, and keeping №2 (20 ergo) untouched as a reserve is valuable.

Also, since the Violet-row charger adds +12 to the **active** battery, we’ll eventually want the active battery to be relatively low when we reach that charger so we don’t waste potential charge (if there’s any cap). So spending down battery №1 first is sensible.

Best move now is progress into the next row while preserving flexibility. Jumping to Red-4 is 5 meters (7 ergo), leaving battery №1 at 5 ergo. Red-4 is also an even platform, so we should still have the option to swap there if needed.

history.location_text:
A soft fall with a roll and a roar of a parturient gobzaurus - you all but fell off the platform that turned out to be surprisingly slippery. You could hardly hold up and saw that the platform had a bad list.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Red-4 (even), so we have a swap device here. Battery №1 is down to 5 ergo, and the only forward jump offered is to Violet-4 (3m), which costs 5 ergo. If we take that jump on battery №1, it will drop to 0 on arrival—bad timing, because the Violet row has the charger (on the central platform), and we ideally want to arrive there with a *partly depleted but nonzero* battery active to benefit from the +12 ergo without getting stranded.

Best plan: swap **now** so battery №2 (20 ergo) pays for the Red→Violet jump, while battery №1 stays at 5 ergo as the spare. Once we’re on Violet-4 (even platform, swap device likely present), we can swap back to battery №1 and then aim for the central Violet platform to get the +12 refill efficiently.

ACTION: 1

history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Red-4 (even), with a swap device available. Active battery №2 is full (20), and battery №1 is the spare with only 5 ergo left. Our next objective in the Violet row is the **central Violet platform** (Violet has 5 platforms, so the center should be №3) because it has the **auto-charger (+12 ergo to the active battery)**.

To maximize the charger’s usefulness, we want to arrive at the central Violet platform with a **low-but-nonzero active battery**. The best setup is:
- First, enter the Violet row by landing on an **even platform** so we can swap batteries there.
- Then swap to battery №1 (5 ergo) and make a short hop to the central platform so it’s low when the +12 triggers.

So we should jump to **Violet-4** (even) rather than Violet-5 (odd, would block swapping immediately). Violet-4 is only 3 meters (5 ergo), which is efficient and preserves options.

history.location_text:
The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Violet-4 (even), so we *can* swap batteries here, but doing so would be harmful right now. Battery №1 (spare) has only 5 ergo, and the key objective in the Violet row is to reach the **central platform (Violet-3)** because it has the **auto-charger (+12 ergo to the active battery)**.

From here, the offered jump to Violet-3 is **6 meters**, which costs **8 ergo**. Battery №1 cannot pay that cost (only 5 ergo), so swapping would strand us immediately. Keeping battery №2 active (15 ergo) lets us make the 6m jump: 15 − 8 = 7 ergo on arrival, then the charger will add +12 to the *active* battery, bringing it up to 19 ergo (no waste even if there’s a cap of 20).

Jumping to Violet-5 instead would avoid the 6m cost, but it delays reaching the charger and puts us on an odd platform with fewer options to manage batteries—so it’s inferior.

ACTION: 2

Jumping to Violet-5 instead would avoid the 6m cost, but it delays reaching the charger and puts us on an odd platform with fewer options to manage batteries—so it’s inferior.

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 7 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 19 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Violet-3 (odd platform), with active battery №2 at 19 ergo and spare battery №1 at 5 ergo. No battery swap is possible here (swap devices only on even-numbered platforms), so our immediate goal is simply to get into the Blue row efficiently while keeping enough charge to handle whatever layout we discover next.

Comparing the jumps:
- To Blue-2: 5 meters = 7 ergo (would leave 12)
- To Blue-3: 2 meters = 4 ergo (would leave 15)
- To Blue-4: 5 meters = 7 ergo (would leave 12)

Since we don’t urgently need to swap right this moment (battery №2 is still healthy), the best strategic move is to **minimize energy spend now** and keep flexibility later. Blue-3 is the cheapest jump, preserving 3 extra ergo compared to the 5-meter options. If we later need access to a swap device, we can still aim for an even platform (Blue-2 or Blue-4) from within the Blue row.

ACTION: 2
history.reasoning:
We’re on Violet-3 (odd platform), with active battery №2 at 19 ergo and spare battery №1 at 5 ergo. No battery swap is possible here (swap devices only on even-numbered platforms), so our immediate goal is simply to get into the Blue row efficiently while keeping enough charge to handle whatever layout we discover next.

Comparing the jumps:
- To Blue-2: 5 meters = 7 ergo (would leave 12)
- To Blue-3: 2 meters = 4 ergo (would leave 15)
- To Blue-4: 5 meters = 7 ergo (would leave 12)

Blue-3 is the cheapest jump, preserving 3 extra ergo compared to the 5-meter options. If we later need access to a swap device, we can still aim for an even platform (Blue-2 or Blue-4) from within the Blue row.

history.location_text:
After landing onto the very edge of the platform, you saw a scratched inscription:
"Bob was h..." - after "h" it was chopped and a long deep scar along with five minor ones stretched to the edge of the platform.

The portable teleport started peeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!
history.llm_response:

history.location_text:
"Ouch!"
The landing was abysmal this time - your feet were burning like on fire, and your completely new space-boots with magnetic soles squished softly and decided to go their own way, bit by bit - the sole of the right boot flew off to the right with a subtle whizz.

The portable teleport started beeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!
There is a battery replacement device here too.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’re on Blue-4 (even), so we have both key safety tools available: a battery replacement device and the one-time portable teleport (usable on Blue/Green). Current energy situation: active battery №2 has 10 ergo; spare battery №1 has 5 ergo.

Swapping batteries now would be counterproductive: we’d make the weak 5-ergo battery active right before a forward jump, risking an immediate drain to 0 and getting stranded on an odd platform with no swap device. So we should keep battery №2 active.

The forward progress option is to Green-3 (3 meters), which costs 5 ergo. That would leave us with 5 ergo active on Green-3. Even if that turns out insufficient to reach the final point, the teleport is still active on the Green row, so we can use it then as a fallback to fully recharge and restart (once). Using the teleport right now would waste our good progress and the Violet recharge advantage without necessity.

So the best move is to advance to Green-3 and reassess from there, keeping the teleport as our emergency contingency.

history.location_text: So you are here again. The Green row is the last one. Why did they paint the last row green, you wonder? It would have been more logical to make it red - most of the accidents happen here. On the other side, if most of the testers were Pelengs with green blood, this colour is matching.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We’ve reached the Green row (last sector before the finish), but the interface currently offers **no jump options to the final point**—only (1) the disposable teleport back to the start or (4) the emergency return button, which explicitly cancels the testing and is an automatic mission failure.

Given the rules, the portable teleport is intended exactly for situations like this: from Blue/Green we can return to the start **once**, fully recharge both batteries, and attempt the run again with better routing/energy management. We still have the teleport unused and charged, so using it is the only non-failing action available and preserves the mission objective.

history.location_text:
You transferred to the starting point. The professor ran to you and hooked up the charger to the batteries:
- So, did you manage to study the labyrinth well enough? Note, you have no more chances to return. And we are pressed for time - we need to format the report, attach it to the application form, register and queue to the acceptance committee. Hurry up, please. You are not the only one after 65535 credits. Honestly, I don't cherish high hopes that you will be a success. The technicians must have done something wrong again reconfiguring the facility. Though they swear that the labyrinth is passable...

You reassured the scholar that you would manage it by all means and got ready for the first jump...
params: You are at the starting point

Now the teleport is spent, so we must follow the known-safe route again, but this time aim for **Green-2** from **Blue-3** (we saw that option earlier), because Green-3 appears to be a trap.

To maximize success, we should start by reproducing the same entry point into the Yellow sector that we know leads onward. Yellow-4 also has a battery replacement device (even platform), which keeps our options open.

So the best first jump is again to **Yellow-4 (6 meters, 8 ergo)**.

history.location_text:
" Ranger Bob was here 1 January 3000", - you saw that inscription for the second time already and these simple words awoke your creativity. Soon a new inscription spread along the platform:
"And ranger Ranger was here twice. 1 January 3000!"

There is a battery replacement device here.

history.location_text:
The platform was flying at you. You tried to remember some prayers but only nasty stories and recipes of the Maloq cuisine came to your mind. You were lucky though and escaped just with fright and injured manhood - fortunately, no self-maiming.

There is a battery replacement device here.
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We are on Violet-4 (even), active battery №2 has 15 ergo, spare battery №1 has only 5 ergo. Our key objective in this sector is the **central Violet platform (Violet-3)** because it has the charger that adds **+12 ergo to the active battery** automatically.

From here to Violet-3 is 6 meters, which costs **8 ergo**. Battery №2 can easily handle that (15 → 7), and then the charger will immediately boost it to **19 ergo**, putting us in strong shape for the remaining rows now that the teleport is spent.

Replacing the battery now would be a logical mistake: battery №1 (5 ergo) cannot pay an 8-ergo jump, so we’d either get stuck or be forced into the detour to Violet-5, risking a dead-end (and losing the clean, proven route). Emergency return is an obvious failure.

So we jump straight to Violet-3 and take the recharge.

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 7 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 19 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.

history.location_text:
You landed near the familiar inscription "Bob was h..." and spent a few minutes immortalising your deed:
"Ranger have been here. I have also been there, and there. And I'm going to jump there.... On the whole, I've been here twice!"
history.llm_response:

From our earlier run we learned a crucial fact: jumping to **Green-3** led to a dead-end interface (no onward jump options), forcing a teleport. Now that teleport is gone, Green-3 is effectively an instant loss risk. The emergency return button is also a guaranteed failure.

That leaves two “serious” routes: detour to Blue-4 or go straight to Green-2. Blue-4 previously only funneled us toward Green-3, so taking Blue-4 again is likely to repeat the same trap, plus it spends extra ergo.

So the correct play is to go directly to **Green-2** (8 meters, 10 ergo). This uses a big chunk of power, but it’s the only known path that avoids the Green-3 dead end and should open the proper finishing jump options.

history.location_text:
And there was your chance, so near, oh so near. It's final point already. One more successful jump - and you are there. If you are a little bit down on your luck, you'll know what they serve in the institute's sick ward. And if it is a bad luck, you'll be able to play genii - you'll be cremated, your ashes will be put in a jug...sorry, in a urn. Some Charley will open it up in tree hundred years and you'll say: 
"I'm all ears and ready to obey, my lord. Shall I break your ribs or train your mother-in-law?" 
Heh, dreaming again!.
history.llm_response:

Replacing the battery doesn’t give any advantage here (both batteries have 5 ergo), and the emergency return button is an obvious mission failure. The optimal, safest choice is to make the final 2-meter jump now and finish the labyrinth.

history.location_text:
Your last jump was unbelievably beautiful - a storm of applause came from underneath and in the last moment you realised that the crowd of on-lookers will soon turn into the crowd of victims because you were landing right on their heads. Fortunately, everything turned out well and nobody was hurt.

- At last! - the professor was shaking your hand in excitement. - We thought we would have to cancel the project due to excess life and health risk. The rectorate started to look awry at us when we receive the bills for the medicine. You deserved your award, Ranger, all you need to do now is to get back to your employer on the Bonnasis planet to take it. By the way, I want to thank you personally.
- What for?
- Don't you understand? I staked half of my yearly salary on you if you go through the labyrinth! By the way, do you want to pocket a little bit more?
params: You are at the finishing point
choices: So what I am supposed to do? To jump while you're staking on me?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- Not at all. It's just additional money. You will get your 65535 credits for sure but you can also earn a little bit more...
- How far is this "more" and what do I need to do?
- See, I'm sure the commission will want to watch the device operating. After you found the best route, any assistant can manage it. Furthermore, your fee is so...formidable that we can't hire you to go through the labyrinth again. But there is one problem - the batteries are spent. I'd like to request you to use one of the first configurations of the testing facility to charge the batteries to the maximum , and I'll pay you 1000 cr. But at first you'll have to jump with the "Jumper" a little bit. You lose nothing and can get some profit - what would you say?
choices: Bad idea, I have already hit my jumping target for the next year. Good bye!
history.llm_response:
REASONING: We have already successfully completed the labyrinth and reached the winning outcome of this stage: the professor explicitly states we will get the **65535 credits for sure**, and this new proposal is **optional extra profit** (+1000 cr) that requires “jumping a little bit” again with **nearly depleted batteries** (active battery only 1 ergo, spare 5 ergo).  

With the portable teleport already spent earlier, we no longer have a safety net for a reset, and any additional jumping introduces unnecessary risk (a bad jump distance, awkward platform parity preventing swaps, or simple accident/bad luck). Since our primary objective is to **finish the quest successfully** and we already have the guaranteed main reward, taking extra trials for minor additional money is strategically unsound: it risks turning a completed success into a failure for no mission-critical benefit.

Therefore I decline and lock in the guaranteed payout.

history.location_text: You left the building of IIII and went to the spaceport. You were very slow and careful going to the aerocab rank and skirted even the smallest puddles and stones.
